speaker: Donald Trump
vclaim: Customs duties are "paid for by China, by the way, not by us."
date: stated on May 9, 2019 in remarks at the White House:
title: Who pays the U.S. duties on Chinese goods? You do.
text: Since President Donald Trump had increased his level of tariff war with China, he had consistently argued that consumers should not be concerned. China ' s Trump was slapped with 25 per cent customs duties on $200 billion in goods and the possibility of imposing tariffs on $325 billion in additional Chinese goods was factored in. At the same time, China is prepared to impose retaliatory tariffs on $60 billion in American products. In notes at the White House on May 9, Trump said, "So our country can take $120 billion a year in tariffs, which China pays for, by the way, not us. A lot of people are trying to steer it in a different direction. It really pays - and ultimately, it pays for it - largely by China. And business will return to our country." He repeated that argument on 13 May / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / Trump suggested some alternatives: purchasing from suppliers in a country without tariffs, or buying from an American company. His repeated message is that Americans should not worry about the economic impact of his definitions, and should formulate his claim by saying that they are "most of them," "really," "large" or "finally" driven by China. Despite the evasive words he used, the experts told us that the President was wrong to offer this kind of assurances. "It is inaccurate to say that "country pays" tariffs on commercial and consumer goods - buyers and sellers bear the costs," said Ross Burkhart, a political scientist at Boise State University. "Porschers pay the tariff when they buy popular products. Vendors lose market share when their products are priced off the market." The White House did not respond to a query about this article. Why do you impose tariffs? The idea behind the imposition of tariffs is to make American firms more competitive with their foreign counterparts. With those companies booming, they go thinking, they can hire more workers and pay their better employees. These workers, in turn, will have more money to spend, and that helps to distribute those dollars around the economy more widely. However, economists have told us that real examples of tariffs that work as intended are rare, and that consumers of a country that raises tariffs are the main victims of tariffs, as they have to pay higher prices. The federal treasury is paid when tariffs are imposed. However, Chinese exporters do not pay. Importers do so - usually American companies. "If the United States imposes a tariff on Chinese television, the duties are paid to United States customs and border protection at the border by an American broker representing an American importer - to transport Costco, Howard Glickman, a senior colleague at the Urban Institute - Brookings Centre for Tax Policy, written in September. "The Chinese government pays nothing." Customs and border protection usually require payment within 10 days of customs clearance of their shipments, and Reuters reported this. Companies that do not pay on that date send a new invoice. How does the cost of tariffs go to consumers? When the tariff is small, the importer may choose to keep its prices stable rather than pass the cost of the tariff to the consumer. However, experts say that this is not the most common decision for the types of tariffs discussed in the current trade war between the United States and China. "When tariffs are imposed by 10 per cent, many companies choose to absorb the cost in their margins," said Monica de Paul, Senior Fellow of the Peterson Institute of International Economics. This can be achieved by stabilizing on lower profit margins or reducing costs in some way. On January 13, 2021, General David Berger, commander of the US Navy, rejected Nancy Belusi's request for the use of marines for security, saying, "We are not working for you." On January 17, 2021, DePaul said, "In any case, with tariffs now increasing to 25%, companies will inevitably move to some or all of the increase to American consumers." "This means that American consumers can in some cases pay 25 percent more for a particular commodity than they did before." At the same time, tariffs may mean that producers pay more, as materials used to make products sold in the United States increase their prices. These price increases are likely to be passed on to consumers as well. American consumers can find tariff-free products elsewhere, but in many cases there may not be an appropriate product, or it may be more expensive or of lower quality. In addition, tariffs can also lead to price delays or price rises throughout the economy, as the economy is now closely intertwined in complex and time-sensitive "supply chains." Any slowdown in the supply chain could mean the demobilization of producers and a blow to the wider American economy. Because studies have shown that low-income Americans tend to spend a larger part of their income on goods, American producers selling to China will be affected by retaliatory tariffs, given China ' s large share of some American agricultural exports, such as soybeans. Finally, Glickman wrote that low competition abroad harms consumers by making them more dependent on less competitive firms with higher prices. How much can the impact on the US economy be? All estimates of potential economic damage from trump tariffs are subject to some degree of speculation. However, the Congressional Research Service recently reviewed a series of professional estimates and found that they "generally suggest a moderate negative impact." A recent study by economists at the Federal Reserve in New York, Princeton University and Columbia University found that "the full frequency of tariff falls on local consumers, with a decline in real United States income of $1.4 billion per month by the end of 2018." The Budget Office of Congress projected a 0.1 per cent decline in the annual GDP growth rate of the United States. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) expects a 0.2 per cent decline in the annual GDP growth rate of the United States. A variety of companies reported damage from the United States and reprisals tariffs, including the Mart, Caterpillar and Tyson Foods, as reported by the Canadian Red Crescent. The United States bears the brunt of tariffs, but China may suffer as well. In the face of rising Chinese commodity prices, consumers in the United States may choose to buy less Chinese goods, which is detrimental to China ' s GDP. But this is not even certain, since China can make up for these sales, or many of those sales, elsewhere. Doesn't tariffs lead to revenue? Tariffs generate some revenue, but economists say it is not wise to rely on tariffs for this purpose. According to the Congressional Research Service, total revenue from the tariffs imposed by Trump as at 21 February 2019 was approximately $18.5 billion. However, this represents only 2 per cent of the federal budget deficit, which has recently been estimated at $896 billion. Our Governor Trump said that definitions are "mostly paid by China, by the way, not by us." China does not pay the initial tariffs - American importers pay them. In many cases, if not in most cases, these costs are passed on to American consumers, whether directly on products affected by tariffs or by influencing American companies using raw materials affected by tariffs. China could also take a long-term blow to its GDP, but experts said that the damage to the American economy would be faster, more certain and more likely. We're assessing the statement wrong.
